subject: Re: How do you handle abbreviations?
msgSnippet: ... latin ... 1) eg ... It varies depending on what the abbreviation means, and these two examples are not both alike. -1- E.g. abbreviates a Latin phrase
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "peter_r_guinness" <malt99@...>
wrote:
>
> How do you folk here handle abbreviations? Do you write them in
latin
> script or spell out the letters with quickscript? For example:
1)"eg"
> <-or-> "27+16+27" ;2)"IBM" <-or-> "31+2+27+28+22"
>

It varies depending on what the abbreviation means, and these two
examples are not both alike.

-1- "E.g." abbreviates a Latin phrase that means "for example", and I
think the best solution is to abbreviate the English phrase instead
of sounding out the "e.g." letters (which BTW would best be
written "27 16+27 underlined"). "For" already has a standard
contraction "9", If you combine that with the Senior Quikscript tall-
X letter to represent the entire word "example", I think you'd have a
perfectly satisfactory two-letter abbreviation that means the same
thing as "e.g.".

-2- IBM is an acronym, rather than a standard abbreviation. Acronyms
are similar to proper names, so I would use the prefix dot and the
sound-alike initial letters, making it ".31 2 22" (actually, I might
be lazy and write ".26 2 22", even though that's phonetically a
little off).
